rev.diff:
Line 4: Line 4:
In the mid-1980s, the [[GNU project]] produced individual free software licences for each of its software packages. The first free licence in history, the [[GCC General Public License]], was applied to the [[GNU Compiler Collection]] and was initially published in 1987.<ref>[http://www.gnu.org/software/gcc/releases.html GCC initial release in 1987]</ref><ref>[http://fsfe.org/projects/gplv3/fisl-rms-transcript.en.html#before-gnu-gpl Stallmans explains the origins of the GNU GPL and mention GCC GPL as an antecedent]</ref> The [[Original BSD license]] is also one of the first free software licences, dating to 1988. In 1989, version 1 of the [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL) was published. Version 2 of the GPL, released in 1991, went on to become the most widely used free software licence.<ref>[http://www.blackducksoftware.com/oss/licenses#top20 Top 20 Most Commonly Used Licenses in Open Source Projects, Black Duck Software].</ref> Starting in the mid-90s and until the mid-00s, a trend began where companies and new projects wrote their own licences, or adapting others' licences to insert their own name. This [[licence proliferation]] led to problems of complexity and [[licence compatibility]].<ref>[http://www.opensource.org/proliferation-report Report of License Proliferation Committee and draft FAQ, Open Source Initiative 2007-12-12].</ref> One free software licence, the GNU GPL version 2, has been brought to court, first in Germany and later in the USA. In the German case the judge did not explicitly discuss the validity of the GPL's clauses but accepted that the GPL had to be adhered to::''If the GPL were not agreed upon by the parties, defendant would notwithstanding lack the necessary rights to copy, distribute, and make the software 'netfilter/iptables' publicly available.''Because the defendant did not comply with the GPL, it had to cease use of the software.<ref>[http://www.groklaw.net/article.php?story=20040725150736471 Harald Welte vs. Sitecom, final order, translated from German by Jens Maurer]</ref> The US case ([[MySQL]] vs Progress) was settled before a verdict was arrived at, but at an initial hearing, Judge Saris "saw no reason" that the GPL would not be enforceable.<ref>See ''Progress Software Corporation v. MySQL AB'', 195 F. Supp. 2d 328 (D. Mass. 2002), on defendant's motion for preliminary injunction.</ref>
In the mid-1980s, the [[GNU project]] produced individual free software licences for each of its software packages. The first free licence in history, the [[GCC General Public License]], was applied to the [[GNU Compiler Collection]] and was initially published in 1987.<ref>[http://www.gnu.org/software/gcc/releases.html GCC initial release in 1987]</ref><ref>[http://fsfe.org/projects/gplv3/fisl-rms-transcript.en.html#before-gnu-gpl Stallmans explains the origins of the GNU GPL and mention GCC GPL as an antecedent]</ref> The [[Original BSD license]] is also one of the first free software licences, dating to 1988. In 1989, version 1 of the [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL) was published. Version 2 of the GPL, released in 1991, went on to become the most widely used free software licence.<ref>[http://www.blackducksoftware.com/oss/licenses#top20 Top 20 Most Commonly Used Licenses in Open Source Projects, Black Duck Software].</ref> Starting in the mid-90s and until the mid-00s, a trend began where companies and new projects wrote their own licences, or adapting others' licences to insert their own name. This [[licence proliferation]] led to problems of complexity and [[licence compatibility]].<ref>[http://www.opensource.org/proliferation-report Report of License Proliferation Committee and draft FAQ, Open Source Initiative 2007-12-12].</ref> One free software licence, the GNU GPL version 2, has been brought to court, first in Germany and later in the USA. In the German case the judge did not explicitly discuss the validity of the GPL's clauses but accepted that the GPL had to be adhered to::''If the GPL were not agreed upon by the parties, defendant would notwithstanding lack the necessary rights to copy, distribute, and make the software 'netfilter/iptables' publicly available.''Because the defendant did not comply with the GPL, it had to cease use of the software.<ref>[http://www.groklaw.net/article.php?story=20040725150736471 Harald Welte vs. Sitecom, final order, translated from German by Jens Maurer]</ref> The US case ([[MySQL]] vs Progress) was settled before a verdict was arrived at, but at an initial hearing, Judge Saris "saw no reason" that the GPL would not be enforceable.<ref>See ''Progress Software Corporation v. MySQL AB'', 195 F. Supp. 2d 328 (D. Mass. 2002), on defendant's motion for preliminary injunction.</ref>
â
==FSF-approved free software licences==
+
==FSF-approved "free software" licences==
[[Free Software Foundation]], the group that maintains [[The Free Software Definition]], maintains a non-exhaustive list of free software licences.<ref>[http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/index_html License list - Free Software Foundation]</ref> The list distinguishes between free software licences that are compatible or incompatible with the FSF licence of choice, the [[GNU General Public License]], which is a [[copyleft]] licence. The list also contains licences which the FSF considers non-free for various reasons, but which are sometimes mistaken as being free.
[[Free Software Foundation]], the group that maintains [[The Free Software Definition]], maintains a non-exhaustive list of free software licences.<ref>[http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/index_html License list - Free Software Foundation]</ref> The list distinguishes between free software licences that are compatible or incompatible with the FSF licence of choice, the [[GNU General Public License]], which is a [[copyleft]] licence. The list also contains licences which the FSF considers non-free for various reasons, but which are sometimes mistaken as being free.
